pageData.text: Learn about bonding and molecular geometry using molecular models. This investigation includes classifying bonds, drawing Lewis structures, predicting molecular geometry, constructing three-dimensional models, and determining polarity. Resonance structures and isomers will also be identified as needed. The activities will require approximately 2 hours to complete.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.desc:
Preparation - 10 minutes
Activity 1: Lewis Dot Structures - 30 minutes
Activity 2: Electron Domain Geometries - 30 minutes
Activity 3: Molecular Geometry - 30 minutes
pageData.altText:
Preparation - 10 minutes
Activity 1: Lewis Dot Structures - 30 minutes
Activity 2: Electron Domain Geometries - 30 minutes
Activity 3: Molecular Geometry - 30 minutes

pageData.subTitle: Overview Video: Lewis Structures and Molecular Shapes

pageData.title: Outcomes
text: Apply valence bond theory to draw appropriate Lewis structures.
Apply valence shell electron pair repulsion theory (VSEPR) to predict molecular geometry.
Sketch three-dimensional line structures using dashed lines and wedges.

pageData.text: Chemical bonding is a cornerstone of the central science of chemistry. One unique example of chemical bonding is the compound known as aerogel. It is also called “liquid smoke” due to its smoky blue appearance. The chemical formula for aerogel is SiO<sub className='bodySubscript'>2</sub> and it forms via a sol-gel polymerization. Simply stated, this sol-gel polymerization process involves simple molecules reacting with other simple molecules by creating crosslinks between them to form the product. There is a great deal of empty space around these crosslinks within the compound, so much so that aerogel is 99.8% air.

This characteristic gives it some very exotic properties, such as withstanding extreme temperatures. Manufacturers have applied it to a variety of products including cosmetics, paints, wetsuits and building insulation. Aerogel also has interesting applications in the space industry, where the material’s use has grown. NASA is using aerogel in its Stardust mission to the comet Wild 2 where it will be used to collect interstellar and comet dust particles to bring home for further study. The Mars Exploration Rover was insulated with aerogel to ensure it stayed warm during its mission.

pageData.desc: A cube of aerogel on display.
pageData.altText: A cube of aerogel on display.

pageData.text: Few elements exist in nature as single atoms. Other than the noble gases, the atoms in most elements are bonded to other atoms. This is because atoms are more stable if their outer energy level is full. Electrons in the outer energy level are called electrons. The halogens (Group 17 in Figure 1) have seven  electrons in their outer energy level.

Each element in group 18 has a full outer energy level. For most elements, a full outer energy level has eight electrons, or an octet. Helium and hydrogen are exceptions in that they only require two <button class='glossary-text'>valence electrons</button>.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Table showing valence shell electrons of atoms
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Table showing valence shell electrons of atoms

pageData.text: Atoms can fill their outer energy level by transferring or sharing electrons to form either ionic or covalent compounds (Figure 2).

pageData.desc: Figure 2: Difference between ionic and covalent bonds
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Difference between ionic and covalent bonds

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Ionic bond</button> (electron is transferred to Y, giving it an octet) <button class='glossary-text'>Covalent bond</button> (two electrons are shared, giving both atoms a filled outer shell) The tendency for atoms to bond ionically or covalently is determined by the difference in their <button class='glossary-text'>electronegativity</button>. Electronegativity is a dimensionless number that is a measure of an atom’s ability to attract bonding <button class='glossary-text'>valence electrons</button>. Electronegativity values show periodic trends on the periodic table, as shown in <button class='resource-text'>Figure 3</button> on the next page.

Excluding the noble gases, the most electronegative element is fluorine, which is assigned a value of 4.0. All the other elements have calculated values based on that of fluorine. Across each period the <button class='glossary-text'>electronegativity</button> tends to increase, with the nonmetal families of nitrogen, oxygen, and fluorine having the highest values. This is because these atoms have smaller radii within which the positive nuclei exert a greater attraction for the <button class='glossary-text'>valence electrons</button>. The alkali metals and alkaline earth metals (the groups on the left side of the periodic table) have the lowest electronegativity because their atoms have the largest radii, within which the positive nuclei exert a smaller attraction for valence electrons. Cesium and francium, with the largest radii, have the lowest electronegativity value of 0.7.

pageData.altText: Periodic table of the electronegativities

pageData.question: Which of the following determines the type of bond that will form between two atoms?

options.text: the difference between their electronegativities
the difference between their atomic radii
their number of valence electrons
the difference between their atomic numbers
their proximity to one another prior to bonding

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The tendency for atoms to bond, either ionically or covalently, is determined by their difference in electronegativity.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes electronegativity?

options.text: a measure of an atom’s ability to attract bonding valence electrons
a term to reference an atom with a full outer energy level of electrons
the number of atoms in 1 gram of a particular element
a measure of the negative charge held by an atom’s valence electrons
a measure of the size of an atom’s radius relative to its number of electron energy levels

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Electronegativity is a dimensionless number that is a measure of an atom’s ability to attract bonding valence electrons.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Atoms can fill their outer energy level by transferring or sharing electrons to form either ionic or covalent compounds. In an ionic bond, an electron from atom X is transferred to Y, giving it an octet. In a covalent bond, two electrons are shared between atoms X and Y, giving both atoms a filled outer shell. The tendency for atoms to bond ionically or covalently is determined by the difference in their electronegativity. Electronegativity is a dimensionless number that is a measure of an atom’s ability to attract bonding valence electrons.

img.alt: Figure 2: Difference between ionic and covalent bonds

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Electronegativity values show periodic trends on the periodic table. Across each period, electronegativity tends to increase. Atoms with smaller radii, such as oxygen or fluorine, have a smaller space within which the positive nuclei exert a greater attraction for the valence electrons. Atoms with larger radii, such as cesium and francium, have the lowest electronegativity because their atoms have the greatest space within which the positive nuclei exert a smaller attraction for valence electrons.

img.alt: Figure 3: Periodic table of the electronegativities

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the electronegativity trend on the periodic table?

options.text: Electronegativity tends to increase across each period.
Electronegativity tends to decrease across each period.
Electronegativity tends to decrease down each group.
Electronegativity is often larger in metal versus nonmetal elements.
Electronegativity is one half the atomic number of each element.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following terms describes electrons in the outer energy level of an atom?

options.text: valence
vector
covalent
ionic
polar

assestmentData.question: Which of the following describes an ionic bond between atoms X and Y?

options.text: X transfers an electron to Y, giving Y an octet.
X shares electrons with Y some of the time, giving both atoms octets.
X shares electrons with Y most of the time, giving both atoms octets.
X has a weak attraction to Y.
X shares electrons with Y evenly, giving both atoms octets.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following electronegativity values indicates an atom has a strong ability to attract bonding valence electrons?

options.text: The balloons are made of latex, to which some individuals are allergic.
The balloons are a potential choking hazard.
The balloons are highly flammable.
The balloons should only be inflated by healthy individuals.
The balloons pose no safety risk.

Read the procedure for each activity.
Obtain all materials.
Separate model pieces into tray compartments based on shape, color, and number of prongs.
Activities 1 and 3 are interrelated. The compounds used in Activity 1 are also used in Activity 3. Data from Data Table 1 will be used for these activities.
In Activity 1, you will choose compounds from a given list to use in this activity and Activity 3. You will then draw Lewis structures of your chosen compounds.

typeBefore.text: A Lewis dot structure is one way to represent the arrangement of <button class='glossary-text'>valence electrons</button> in a molecule. In Lewis structures, each element symbol is surrounded by a specific number of dots representing valence electrons. Most atoms obey the octet rule*, which states that atoms tend to combine in such a way that they each have eight electrons in their valence shells, giving them the same electronic configuration as a noble gas.

To fill their outer shells, elements form <button class='glossary-text'>covalent bonds</button> by sharing electrons. Lewis structures are often used to show those bonds. Covalent compounds may have single, double, or triple bonds between atoms. These bonds are represented in a Lewis structure by dashes between the chemical symbols of the bonded elements. The number of dashes corresponds to the number of bonds. Lewis structures also indicate the lone pairs of electrons on different atoms.

pageData.text: Choose three compounds from Group 1, three compounds from Group 2, and three compounds from Group 3 to use in Activities 1 and 3.
Draw Lewis dot structures for each of your chosen compounds following the guidelines in Table 2.
Photograph your drawings.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: *Exceptions: Hydrogen and helium need only two valence electrons to fill their outer shell. Boron and beryllium form compounds with less than eight electrons and elements in periods 3–6 may use more than eight.

tableData.text: 1. Determine the number of valence electrons present for each atom in the compound (consult Figure 1 in the background section as needed).

Silicon (Si): 4 valence electrons

Oxygen (O): 6 valence electrons

Oxygen (O): 6 valence electrons
tableData.hoverText: Silicon (Si): 4 valence electrons Oxygen (O): 6 valence electrons Oxygen (O): 6 valence electrons

tableData.text: 2. Find the sum of the valence electrons. If there is a charge on a compound, add an electron for each negative charge and subtract an electron for each positive charge.

Silicon (Si): 4 valence electrons

Oxygen (O): 6 valence electrons

Oxygen (O): 6 valence electrons/ 16 total electrons
tableData.hoverText: Silicon (Si): 4 valence electrons Oxygen (O): 6 valence electrons Oxygen (O): 6 valence electrons = 16 total electrons

tableData.text: 3. Determine which atom is to be the central atom. This is typically the least electronegative element (that is not hydrogen) and/or the first element in the chemical formula. Some compounds will have no central atom, but the first element in the formula is a good place to start.

tableData.hoverText: The atomic symbol Si

tableData.text: 4. Write the chemical symbol of the central atom, followed by the chemical symbols for other atoms around it.

tableData.hoverText: The atomic symbol O on the left, the atomic symbol Si in the middle, and a second atomic symbol O on the right.

tableData.text: 5. Use dots to show the appropriate number of valence electrons around each symbol in the compound, based on their position in the periodic table.

tableData.hoverText: The atomic symbol O on the left surrounded by 6 dots, the atomic symbol Si surrounded by 4 dots, and a second atomic symbol O surrounded by 6 dots.

tableData.text: 6. Determine the total number of electrons required for each element. Allow for exceptions to the octet rule as needed.

Silicon (Si) needs 8 valence electrons

Oxygen (O) needs 8 valence electrons

Oxygen (O) needs 8 valence electrons
tableData.hoverText: Silicon (Si) needs 8 valence electrons Oxygen (O) needs 8 valence electrons Oxygen (O) needs 8 valence electrons

tableData.text: 7. Create a skeleton structure by connecting unpaired electrons from the central atom to unpaired electrons on the atoms around it with a solid line. Each solid line now represents a (two-electron) covalent bond between the two atoms.

tableData.hoverText: The Lewis dot structure for silicon dioxide. The left oxygen symbol is surrounded by 6 dots, with 2 of those dots placed between the oxygen and the silicon symbols. The middle silicon symbol is surrounded by 8 total dots. The right oxygen symbol is surrounded by 6 dots, with 2 of those dots placed between the oxygen and silicon symbols, and which are already part of the 8 total dots surrounding the silicon symbol.

tableData.text: 8. Redraw the structure as needed. If multiple bonds exist between two atoms, reorient the chemical symbols so that multiple bonds are with each other.

tableData.hoverText: The Lewis dot structure for silicon dioxide. A single bond connects the left oxygen symbol to the middle silicon symbol. A second single bond connects the middle silicon symbol to the right oxygen symbol. Each symbol has 2 dots above and below its symbol.

tableData.text:
9. Sometimes there will be more than one way to add the bonds. To determine which Lewis structure is the best model, formal charge is often used. To determine the formal charge of atoms:
  1. Count the number of valence electrons that each atom typically has when unbound.
  2. In the Lewis structure being evaluated, count the number of assigned electrons for an atom by counting the number of electrons that exist around that atom as lone pairs and then counting the number of covalent bonds on that atom. Add the number of lone pair electrons and the number of bonds together.
  3. Subtract the number of assigned electrons from the number of electrons. The resulting value is the formal charge for the atom in that Lewis structure.
.
tableData.hoverText: 9. Sometimes there will be more than one way to add the bonds. To determine which Lewis structure is the best model, formal charge is often used. To determine the formal charge of atoms: a. Count the number of valence electrons that each atom typically has when unbound. b. In the Lewis structure being evaluated, count the number of assigned electrons for an atom by counting the number of electrons that exist around that atom as lone pairs and then counting the number of covalent bonds on that atom. Add the number of lone pair electrons and the number of bonds together. c. Subtract the number of assigned electrons from the number of valance electrons. The resulting value is the formal charge for the atom in that Lewis structure.

A Lewis dot structure of silicon dioxide with double bonds between the silicon atom and each oxygen atom. Each oxygen atom has 2 dots above and below its symbol. A table shows the unbound electron count for each oxygen atom is 6, and for the silicon atom, 4; the assigned electron count for each oxygen atom is -6, and for the silicon atom, -4; the formal charge for each atom is 0. A second Lewis dot structure of silicon dioxide with the silicon atom bound by a triple bond to the left oxygen atom, and by a single bond to the right oxygen atom. The left oxygen atom has 2 dots above its symbol; the right oxygen atom has 6 dots around its symbol. A second table shows the unbound electron count for each oxygen atom is 6, and for the silicon atom, 4; the assigned electron count for the left oxygen atom is -7, for the silicon atom, -4, and for the right oxygen atom, -5; the formal charge for the left oxygen atom is -1, for the silicon atom, 0, and for the right oxygen atom, +1.

tableData.text: 10. Lewis structures should show negative charges on the most electronegative elements and positive charges on the least electronegative elements.

tableData.hoverText: A Lewis dot structure of silicon dioxide with double bonds between the silicon atom and each oxygen atom. Each oxygen atom has 2 dots above and below its symbol. This is the preferred structure of silicon dioxide.

pageData.text: In Activity 2, you will build electron domain geometries using balloons.
Inflate a balloon and tie the open end in a knot.

typeBefore.text: The three-dimensional shape of a molecule is predicted using the valence-shell electron-pair repulsion (VSEPR) model. The VSEPR model is used to predict structures of molecules or ions that contain only nonmetals by minimizing the electrostatic repulsion between the regions of high electron density. In this activity, balloons will model electron domains. An electron domain is either a bond or a lone pair of electrons. Double and triple bonds count as only one domain when using the VSEPR model. When tied together, balloons naturally adopt the lowest energy arrangement predicted by the VSEPR model.Linear Geometry – Two Electron Domains

pageData.text: Repeat to prepare a second balloon of approximately the same size.
Tie the two balloons together in a knot.
Label and photograph the model for future reference.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Inflate and tie three balloons.

typeBefore.title: Trigonal Planar Geometry – Three Electron Domains

pageData.text: Tie the three balloons together. Start by tying two balloons together and then use the free ends to knot around the third.
Label and photograph the model for future reference.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Inflate and tie four balloons.
Tie the balloons together to form two sets of two balloons.
Twist the two sets of two balloons together by crossing the knotted centers.
Label and photograph the model for future reference.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Inflate and tie five balloons.

typeBefore.title: Trigonal Bipyramidal Geometry – Five Electron Domains

pageData.text: Tie four balloons together to form two sets of two balloons.
Tie a third balloon to one of the sets.
Twist the set of three balloons and the set of two balloons together by crossing the knotted centers.
Label and photograph the model for future reference.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Inflate and tie six balloons.
Tie the balloons together to form three sets of two balloons.
Twist two sets of two balloons together by crossing the knotted centers. Twist a third set of two balloons into the other two by crossing the knotted centers.
Label and photograph the model for future reference.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: In Activity 3, you will build three-dimensional models of your chosen compounds from Activity 1 using the molecular modeling pieces. You will then draw a perspective drawing of each model using wedge-and-dash notation to show three dimensions.

Construct a three-dimensional model of each molecule from Activity 1 using the following molecular model pieces to represent atoms.
  1. White one-pronged: Hydrogen
  2. Light green one-pronged: All other atoms
  3. Dark brown three-pronged: Atoms with only three electron pairs and/or bonds
  4. Black, four-pronged: Carbon
  5. Blue, four-pronged: Nitrogen
  6. Red, four-pronged: Oxygen
  7. Purple five-pronged (and/or bonds): Atoms with five electron pairs
  8. Silver six-pronged: Atoms with six electron pairs and/or bonds
Use white tubes to connect the pronged pieces and represent between atoms in each molecule.As needed, connect the white, flat pieces for electron pairs on the central atom.

typeBefore.title: Bonding and Molecular Geometry
typeBefore.text: In this activity, you will use the same compounds selected in Activity 1 from <button class='resource-text'>Table 1</button>.

pageData.desc: Figure 4: Table of electron domains, bond angles and three dimensional shapes
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Table of electron domains, bond angles and three dimensional shapes

pageData.text: Use the white tubes to form bonds between the atoms. Each tube represents one bond (two electrons). For a double bond, use two tubes and two prongs on each atom.
Sketch a perspective drawing of each compound. If necessary, use wedges and dashes to show the three-dimensional appearance using Figure 5.
For one compound from each Group, place the model next to its perspective drawing and take a photograph.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: For each compound, determine the number of domains, the number of lone pairs, the molecule's geometry, and the bond angle. Record these values in Data Table 1.

pageData.desc: Figure 5: Table of electron domains and shapes of molecules using wedge and dash notation
pageData.altText: Figure 5: Table of electron domains and shapes of molecules using wedge and dash notation

tableData.text: 3. Determine which atom is to be the central atom. This is typically the least electronegative element (that is not hydrogen) and/or the first element in the chemical formula. Some compounds will have no central atom, but the first element in the formula is a good place to start.

tableData.text: 7. Create a skeleton structure by connecting unpaired electrons from the central atom to unpaired electrons on the atoms around it with a solid line. Each solid line now represents a (two-electron) covalent bond between the two atoms.

The middle silicon symbol is surrounded by 8 total dots. The right oxygen symbol is surrounded by 6 dots, with 2 of those dots placed between the oxygen and silicon symbols, and which are already part of the 8 total dots surrounding the silicon symbol.

tableData.text: 8. Redraw the structure as needed. If multiple bonds exist between two atoms, reorient the chemical symbols so that multiple bonds are with each other.

tableData.text:
9. Sometimes there will be more than one way to add the bonds. To determine which Lewis structure is the best model, formal charge is often used. To determine the formal charge of atoms:
  1. Count the number of valence electrons that each atom typically has when unbound.
  2. In the Lewis structure being evaluated, count the number of assigned electrons for an atom by counting the number of electrons that exist around that atom as lone pairs and then counting the number of covalent bonds on that atom. Add the number of lone pair electrons and the number of bonds together.
  3. Subtract the number of assigned electrons from the number of electrons. The resulting value is the formal charge for the atom in that Lewis structure.
.
tableData.hoverText: 9. Sometimes there will be more than one way to add the bonds. To determine which Lewis structure is the best model, formal charge is often used. To determine the formal charge of atoms: a. Count the number of valence electrons that each atom typically has when unbound. b. In the Lewis structure being evaluated, count the number of assigned electrons for an atom by counting the number of electrons that exist around that atom as lone pairs and then counting the number of covalent bonds on that atom. Add the number of lone pair electrons and the number of bonds together. c. Subtract the number of assigned electrons from the number of valance electrons. The resulting value is the formal charge for the atom in that Lewis structure.

A Lewis dot structure of silicon dioxide with double bonds between the silicon atom and each oxygen atom. Each oxygen atom has 2 dots above and below its symbol. A table shows the unbound electron count for each oxygen atom is 6, and for the silicon atom, 4; the assigned electron count for each oxygen atom is -6, and for the silicon atom, -4; the formal charge for each atom is 0. A second Lewis dot structure of silicon dioxide with the silicon atom bound by a triple bond to the left oxygen atom, and by a single bond to the right oxygen atom. The left oxygen atom has 2 dots above its symbol; the right oxygen atom has 6 dots around its symbol. A second table shows the unbound electron count for each oxygen atom is 6, and for the silicon atom, 4; the assigned electron count for the left oxygen atom is -7, for the silicon atom, -4, and for the right oxygen atom, -5; the formal charge for the left oxygen atom is -1, for the silicon atom, 0, and for the right oxygen atom, +1.

tableData.text: 10. Lewis structures should show negative charges on the most electronegative elements and positive charges on the least electronegative elements.

tableData.hoverText: A Lewis dot structure of silicon dioxide with double bonds between the silicon atom and each oxygen atom. Each oxygen atom has 2 dots above and below its symbol. This is the preferred structure of silicon dioxide.

data.title: Covalent bond
data.content: A chemical bond in which there is a sharing of an electron pair between two atoms, giving both atoms a filled outer shell

data.title: Electronegativity
data.content: A dimensionless number that is a measure of an atom’s ability to attract bonding valence electrons

data.title: Ionic bond
data.content: A chemical bond formed when one atom, typically a non-metal atom, gives up one or more electrons to another atom, typically a metal atom, resulting in ions with filled outer shells for both the metal and non-metal atoms

data.title: Valence electrons
data.content: Electrons in the outer energy level
